abstract.t: This document defines the SUSPEND extension for the IMAP protocol. It provides a method for a client to save the current configuration state of an IMAP session and then quickly restore this configuration in a subsequent session.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: [TODO: Reorganize this section. Disconnected talk should probably go lower in section, after talk about activating extensions.]

The original IMAP4rev1 protocol specification was primarily designed to be used by clients that remain connected to the IMAP server for extended periods of time. Since that time, "disconnected" IMAP clients have become increasingly popular and numerous, due to the rise in, for example, portable devices that do not maintain persistent connections to the remove server, or for which keeping an active connection is expensive (in terms of computing and/or power).

In response to the rise of these disconnected clients, various IMAP extensions have been developed to assist in accessing the remote account. [TODO: Links to LEMONADE profile? UIDPLUS?] Some of these extensions, such as QRESYNC, require explicit action by the client in order to activate their features.
Other advanced IMAP features, such as the LANGUAGE command, also require explicit configuration by the client and is forgotten when the client logs out of the server [TODO: mention NOTIFY?].

Finally, there is additional overhead when connecting to an IMAP server (e.g. entering authenticated state) because the client needs to do things like determine the capabilities of the remote server (CAPABILITY command) and, if available, to obtain the namespace layout for the mailboxes (NAMESPACE command).

Therefore, a disconnected client still faces the (potentially substantial) overhead of needing to perform various initialization initialization tasks before the client can begin to do "useful" work from the perspective of the end user (e.g. listing mailboxes accessing messages). For clients that are unable to maintain a persistent connection the server, many of the gains provided by the advanced IMAP extensions are offset by the overhead to enable and confgure them on every access.
The SUSPEND extension provides a mechanism for a client to save the configuration state of an existing session and then quickly re-establish this configuration in subsequent server connections.
An IMAP server that supports SUSPEND advertises this by including the word SUSPEND in its capability list.

section.title: Requirements Language
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

In examples, lines beginning with "S:" are sent by the IMAP server, and lines beginning with "C:" are sent by the client. Line breaks may appear in example commands solely for editorial clarity; when present in the actual message, they are represented by "CRLF".

section.title: SUSPEND Command

list.t: REQUIRED untagged response: BYE OPTIONAL untagged response: SUSPEND
OK - logout completed BAD - command unknown or arguments invalid

section.t: This section defines a new SUSPEND command.

To close the connection with the server, the LOGOUT command is issued. The SUSPEND command extends the LOGOUT command by indicating to the server that, in addition to closing the network connection, the client also requests that the current configuration state be saved.
If the current IMAP configuration state can be saved, an untagged SUSPEND response (see ) MUST be issued. If the server cannot save the current state, a SUSPEND response MUST NOT be issued.
Like the LOGOUT command, a server MUST send a BYE untagged response before the (tagged) OK response, and then close the network connection.

section.title: RESUME Command

list.t: no specific response for this command
OK - suspend token is valid NO - suspend token is invalid BAD - command unknown or arguments invalid

section.t: This section defines a new RESUME command.
This command is used when a client desires to restore the configuration state represented by a token previously generated by the server.
The RESUME command MUST only be issued in either the not authenticated state or in the authenticated state. If the RESUME command is issued in the selected state, a BAD tagged response MUST be sent.

If the command is sent in the not authenticated state, the client is indicating that it desires the restore the configuration state represented by the token after authentication is completed. If the command is issued in the authenticated state, the client is requesting that the current IMAP configuration be immediately switched to the configuration state indicated by the token.
If issued in the not authenticated state, the RESUME command SHOULD NOT be issued until the TLS layer has been negotiated.
If the token is invalid or has expired, the RESUME command MUST return a tagged NO response.

If the token is valid, the RESUME command MUST return a tagged OK response. This does NOT mean that the configuration state has been restored; that only occurs after the server issues a RESUME response code (see ).

If the server can successfully restore the state indicated by the given token, it MUST issue an tagged OK response. This restored session MUST be identical to the state at the time the SUSPEND command that issued the token was issued. After a successful RESUME command, the connection MUST be in the authenticated state (i.e. no mailbox is selected).

section.title: SUSPEND Response
section.t: The SUSPEND response occurs as a result of a SUSPEND command. The suspend token is a server-specific representation of the current configuration state of the IMAP session.
[todo: A suspend token MUST become invalid if either the NAMESPACE or CAPABILITY configuration of the server changes.]

It is RECOMMENDED that the suspend token contain a versioning mechanism that would cause the token to be unsuccessful in restoring state if the internal state storage mechanism in the server changes. However, interpretation of the contents or format of the suspend token is left entirely to the server implementor.

section.title: RESUME Response Code
section.t:
This section defines a new RESUME response code:
OK [RESUME <suspend-token>]
where <suspend-token> is the token identifier associated with the configuration state that was restored.
If a client issued a successful RESUME command in the not authenticated state, this response code MUST be issued in response to the authentication command.
If a client issued a successful RESUME command in the authenticated state, this response code MUST be issued in the response to the RESUME command.

section.title: Client
section.t: [todo: Successfully resuming a session guarantees that the NAMESPACE and CAPABILITY values of the server have not changed. A client is RECOMMENDED to cache these values locally. Not sure if this is even needed, since it is a/the main reason to use this extension.]

section.title: Server
section.t: If a session is successfully resumed via a RESUME command issued before authentication, the client is assumed to be using a cached version of the CAPABILITY list. Therefore, a server SHOULD NOT automatically issue a CAPABILITY response code as a result of the authentication command since the client will already have this information.

section.title: Examples
section.t:
Example 1: A client connects to a server and does not have a saved suspend token. The client verifies that the server supports the the SUSPEND extension, performs its initialization, and obtains a suspend token.
<Client successfully authenticates to server> C: A1 CAPABILITY S: * CAPABILITY IMAP4rev1 ENABLE QRESYNC I18NLEVEL=1 SUSPEND S: A1 OK Capability command completed. C: A2 ENABLE QRESYNC S: * ENABLED QRESYNC S: A2 OK Enable command completed. C: A3 LANGUAGE DE S: * LANGUAGE (DE) S: * NAMESPACE (("" "/")) (("Other Users/" "/" "TRANSLATION" ("Andere Ben&APw-tzer/"))) (("Public Folders/" "/" "TRANSLATION" ("Gemeinsame Postf&AM8-cher/"))) S: A3 Sprachwechsel durch LANGUAGE-Befehl ausgefuehrt [...] C: A20 SUSPEND S: * SUSPEND c3RhdGUgdG9rZW4= S: * BYE Server logging out. S: A20 OK Logout completed.

Example 2: The client in Example 1 connects at a future time to the same server and seeks to restore the previous IMAP session.
C: * OK [CAPABILITY IMAP4rev1 STARTTLS LOGINDISABLED SUSPEND] C: A1 STARTTLS S: A1 OK Being TLS negotiation now. <TLS negotiation, further commands are under TLS layer> C: A2 CAPABILITY S: * CAPABILITY IMAP4rev1 AUTH=PLAIN SUSPEND S: A2 OK CAPABILITY completed. C: A3 RESUME c3RhdGUgdG9rZW4= S: A3 OK Suspend token valid. C: A4 LOGIN joe passwd S: A4 OK [RESUME c3RhdGUgdG9rZW4=] LOGIN completed and configuration restored.

Example 3: The client in Example 1 connects at a future time to the same server and seeks to restore the previous IMAP session. In this example, the connection was pre-authenticated so the RESUME command is issued in the authenticated state.
S: * PREAUTH [CAPABILITY IMAP4rev1 ENABLE QRESYNC I18NLEVEL=1 SUSPEND] C: A1 RESUME c3RhdGUgdG9rZW4= S: A1 OK [RESUME c3RhdGUgdG9rZW4=] Configuration restored.

section.title: Formal Syntax
section.t: The following syntax specification uses the Augmented Backus-Naur Form (ABNF) as described in . Terms not defined here are taken from .

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: The IANA is requested to add SUSPEND to the "IMAP 4 Capabilities" registry, http://www.iana.org/assignments/imap4-capabilities.

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: It is believed that this extension doesn't add any security considerations that are not already present in the base IMAP protocol .
